<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Two two-dimension homochiral Ag (I) metal frameworks constructed from enantiopure camphor-10-sulfonic acid and hexamethylenetetramine have been synthesized at the room temperature. These two complexes with (6, 3) topology decorated by the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid possess the unique helical structures. The result of Circular Dichroism (CD) spectroscopy confirms that the bulk materials are homochiral and also indicates the handedness of the single crystals can be controlled by the chirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acid.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two two-dimension homochiral Ag (I) metal frameworks constructed from enantiopure camphor-10-sulfonic acid and hexamethylenetetramine have been synthesized at the room temperature. These two complexes with (6, 3) topology decorated by the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid possess the unique helical structures. The result of Circular Dichroism (CD) spectroscopy confirms that the bulk materials are homochiral and also indicates the handedness of the single crystals can be controlled by the chirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acid.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0015" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The design and synthesis of homochiral solids have drawn increasing attention owing to their interesting properties and potential applications in asymmetric catalysis , enantioselective catalysis , and nonlinear optics . For inorganic oxides, the chirality must come from the spatial organization (usually helices) of achiral units . Nowadays, the rapid development of metal-organic framework materials (MOFs)  opens an avenue to construct homochiral solids with intriguing topologies and diverse structural architectures. The utilization of enantiopure ligands might fabricate homochiral MOFs , however, the undesirable achiral product was sometimes obtained owing to the ligand racemization . Achiral precursors could create chiral solids with helical structures. Although each single crystal is chiral attributed to crystallization in a chiral space group, the mixture of products perform no optical activity，that is to say, right-handed and left-handed single ones crystallize in an equal proportion called conglomerates. Homochiral single crystal could be further obtained by using homochiral catalysis elaborated by Bu  or homochiral solvents such as homochiral ionic liquids motivated by Morris .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Introduction

The design and synthesis of homochiral solids have drawn increasing attention owing to their interesting properties and potential applications in asymmetric catalysis , enantioselective catalysis , and nonlinear optics . For inorganic oxides, the chirality must come from the spatial organization (usually helices) of achiral units . Nowadays, the rapid development of metal-organic framework materials (MOFs)  opens an avenue to construct homochiral solids with intriguing topologies and diverse structural architectures. The utilization of enantiopure ligands might fabricate homochiral MOFs , however, the undesirable achiral product was sometimes obtained owing to the ligand racemization . Achiral precursors could create chiral solids with helical structures. Although each single crystal is chiral attributed to crystallization in a chiral space group, the mixture of products perform no optical activity，that is to say, right-handed and left-handed single ones crystallize in an equal proportion called conglomerates. Homochiral single crystal could be further obtained by using homochiral catalysis elaborated by Bu  or homochiral solvents such as homochiral ionic liquids motivated by Morris .

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">It is a promising and efficient way to create homochiral single crystals by the availability of enantiopure bridging ligands. Due to the quite inert chiral center in the structure of homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid, it is unlikely to racemize so that it can be better used to synthesize the homochiral materials. Simultaneously, sulfonic acid prefers to coordinate to Ag (I) ion rather than other transition metals (such as Fe<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>), especially the auxiliary N-containing secondary ligands included, which was systematically investigated and elaborately elucidated by Ma’s ，Chen’s  and Shimizu’s group . However, few of these structures based on Ag (I) ion are homochiral. So it is a fresh opportunity for us to generate homochiral single crystals containing Ag (I) ion and enantiopure camphor-10-sulfonic acid.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is a promising and efficient way to create homochiral single crystals by the availability of enantiopure bridging ligands. Due to the quite inert chiral center in the structure of homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid, it is unlikely to racemize so that it can be better used to synthesize the homochiral materials. Simultaneously, sulfonic acid prefers to coordinate to Ag (I) ion rather than other transition metals (such as Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+), especially the auxiliary N-containing secondary ligands included, which was systematically investigated and elaborately elucidated by Ma's ，Chen's  and Shimizu's group . However, few of these structures based on Ag (I) ion are homochiral. So it is a fresh opportunity for us to generate homochiral single crystals containing Ag (I) ion and enantiopure camphor-10-sulfonic acid.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Herein we reported two homochiral silver camphor-10-sulfonic acid frameworks [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(L2)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-L1)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·11H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (complex 1), [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (L3)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-L1)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·11H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (complex 2) [L1 = hexamethylenetetramine, L2 = (+)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion, L3= (−)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>)] constructed from a two-dimension undulating (6, 3) net decorated by the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acids. It is worth noting that the two-dimension net is composed of the left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein we reported two homochiral silver camphor-10-sulfonic acid frameworks [Ag6(H2O)6(L2)6 (μ3-L1)6⋅11H2O]n (complex 1), [Ag6(H2O)6 (L3)6 (μ3-L1)6⋅11H2O]n (complex 2) [L1 = hexamethylenetetramine, L2 = (+)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion, L3= (-)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion ( )] constructed from a two-dimension undulating (6, 3) net decorated by the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acids. It is worth noting that the two-dimension net is composed of the left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical structures.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. The crystalline products were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), single crystal XRD, CD spectra and thermal analysis. Thermal analysis was conducted on a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. The sample of 1 (3.108 mg) or 2 (4.940 mg) was heated under a nitrogen stream with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the range of 40–700 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Focus diffractometer with Cu KR radiation and a Lynx Eye detector at a scanning rate of 3°/min in the 2 θ range of 10–50°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and instrumentation

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. The crystalline products were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), single crystal XRD, CD spectra and thermal analysis. Thermal analysis was conducted on a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. The sample of 1 (3.108 mg) or 2 (4.940 mg) was heated under a nitrogen stream with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the range of 40-700 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Focus diffractometer with Cu KR radiation and a Lynx Eye detector at a scanning rate of 3°/min in the 2 θ range of 10-50°.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of the two complexes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">(+)-Camphor-10-sulfonic acids (0.116 g, 0.5 mmol) and hexamine (0.5 mmol, 0.07g) were added to an aqueous solution (10 mL) of acetic acid silver (0.5 mmol, 0.084g). After the mixture was stirred for 15 min, the precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous solution of NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (14M). Colorless crystals of complex 1 were obtained by evaporation of the solution for 5 days at room temperature (52% yield). The complex 2 was obtained by the same method with the (−)-camphor-10-sulfonic acids.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the two complexes

(+)-Camphor-10-sulfonic acids (0.116 g, 0.5 mmol) and hexamine (0.5 mmol, 0.07g) were added to an aqueous solution (10 mL) of acetic acid silver (0.5 mmol, 0.084g). After the mixture was stirred for 15 min, the precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous solution of NH3 (14M). Colorless crystals of complex 1 were obtained by evaporation of the solution for 5 days at room temperature (52% yield). The complex 2 was obtained by the same method with the (-)-camphor-10-sulfonic acids.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Determinations of crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The X-ray intensity data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Ka radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71073 A°) operated at 2.0 kW (50 kV, 40 mA). The crystal structure was solved by means of Direct Methods and refined employing full-matrix least squares on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (SHELXTL-97). Crystallographic data and structural refinements are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Determinations of crystal structures

The X-ray intensity data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 A°) operated at 2.0 kW (50 kV, 40 mA). The crystal structure was solved by means of Direct Methods and refined employing full-matrix least squares on F2 (SHELXTL-97). Crystallographic data and structural refinements are summarized in  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Single crystal structure description of complex 1</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Complex 1 crystallizes in chiral space group P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, and there are six crystallographically independent Ag (I) ions, six L1 ligands, six L2 ligands, six coordinated waters and eleven lattice waters in the asymmetry unit. All Ag (I) ions show a distorted five coordination trigonalbiyramid configuration with N atoms from L1 ligands in square positions and two O atoms in apical position (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The coordinated water interacts with the Ag ion very weakly (the average distance of Ag ion and coordinated water is 3.02 Å). The eleven lattice waters were also deduced from the lost weight (about 6%) of TG curve of complex 1 ().The Ag-N bonds ranging from 2.2909 (0.0045) Å to 2.3808 (0.0047) Å  are similar to the reported values, so do the Ag-O<ce:inf loc="post">camphor-10-sulfonic</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">acids</ce:inf> ones ranging from 2.592 Å to 2.684 Å . In complex 1 (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>), by considering both Ag ions and L1 ligands as three-connected nodes, it can be represented as a chiral (6, 3) nets (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>) because of the fact that although the (6, 3) net is not intrinsically chiral (quartz and zeolite β topologies are intrinsic chiral ones) , it is decorated by the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid. It is a new strategy to utilize the enantiopure ligands to construct such chiral topologies as diamond  and PtS ones  which are not intrinsic chiral topology.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Single crystal structure description of complex 1

Complex 1 crystallizes in chiral space group P21, and there are six crystallographically independent Ag (I) ions, six L1 ligands, six L2 ligands, six coordinated waters and eleven lattice waters in the asymmetry unit. All Ag (I) ions show a distorted five coordination trigonalbiyramid configuration with N atoms from L1 ligands in square positions and two O atoms in apical position ( ). The coordinated water interacts with the Ag ion very weakly (the average distance of Ag ion and coordinated water is 3.02 Å). The eleven lattice waters were also deduced from the lost weight (about 6%) of TG curve of complex 1 ().The Ag-N bonds ranging from 2.2909 (0.0045) Å to 2.3808 (0.0047) Å  are similar to the reported values, so do the Ag-Ocamphor-10-sulfonic acids ones ranging from 2.592 Å to 2.684 Å . In complex 1 ( ), by considering both Ag ions and L1 ligands as three-connected nodes, it can be represented as a chiral (6, 3) nets ( ) because of the fact that although the (6, 3) net is not intrinsically chiral (quartz and zeolite β topologies are intrinsic chiral ones) , it is decorated by the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid. It is a new strategy to utilize the enantiopure ligands to construct such chiral topologies as diamond  and PtS ones  which are not intrinsic chiral topology.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In the Ag- hexamethylenetetramine system, albeit the (6, 3) net is very common among the six types of two-dimensional Ag–L1 layers , few such layers are constructed from both the left-handed and right-handed helical structures. In the complex 1, there are two layers named layer A (Ag1, Ag2, and Ag3 accommodate in this layer) and layer B (Ag4, Ag5, and Ag6 reside in this layer). In the layer A of the complex 1, it is of particular interest to note that the left-handed 2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> helices along b axis ((a)<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>) are constructed from Ag1 ions, Ag3 ions and L1 ligands ((b)). (c) illustrates that M helical structure is also made up of Ag1-L1-Ag3 but revolves 180°compared to the structure mentioned in the (b) along the b axis. The P helical structures are generated by the Ag3-L1-Ag3 system ((d)) and Ag2-L1-Ag2 one ((e)) along b axis, respectively. From the , we can know the facts that 1) P<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and M<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> are connected through sharing the L1 ligands and Ag3 ions; 2) P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and M<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> are joined by the bonds Ag2-N while P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are done through interaction between Ag1 ions and L1 ligands. All these helixes are decorated by the (+)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion which coordinates with the Ag (I) ion so that the neutrally extended (6, 3) nets are formed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the Ag- hexamethylenetetramine system, albeit the (6, 3) net is very common among the six types of two-dimensional Ag-L1 layers , few such layers are constructed from both the left-handed and right-handed helical structures. In the complex 1, there are two layers named layer A (Ag1, Ag2, and Ag3 accommodate in this layer) and layer B (Ag4, Ag5, and Ag6 reside in this layer). In the layer A of the complex 1, it is of particular interest to note that the left-handed 21 helices along b axis ((a)) are constructed from Ag1 ions, Ag3 ions and L1 ligands ((b)). (c) illustrates that M helical structure is also made up of Ag1-L1-Ag3 but revolves 180°compared to the structure mentioned in the (b) along the b axis. The P helical structures are generated by the Ag3-L1-Ag3 system ((d)) and Ag2-L1-Ag2 one ((e)) along b axis, respectively. From the , we can know the facts that 1) P1 and M1 are connected through sharing the L1 ligands and Ag3 ions; 2) P2 and M1 are joined by the bonds Ag2-N while P2 and M2 are done through interaction between Ag1 ions and L1 ligands. All these helixes are decorated by the (+)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion which coordinates with the Ag (I) ion so that the neutrally extended (6, 3) nets are formed.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Interestingly, the handedness of all the helical structures in the layer B of the complex 1((a)<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>) and ones in the layer A are totally opposite. For example, helical structure made up of the Ag4 ion, Ag6 ion and L1 is right-handed in the layer B ((b)) while the one in the layer A is left-handed. The same situations happen in the P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ((c)), M<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> ((d)), and M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ((e)) in the layer B. It seems as if the symmetry of complex 1 should have been improved, however, the homochirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acids destroys the mirror symmetry. The fact that the complex 1 indeed crystallizes in the chiral space group is soundly supported by the Circular Dichroism. All the helical structures are also decorated by the (+)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the handedness of all the helical structures in the layer B of the complex 1((a)) and ones in the layer A are totally opposite. For example, helical structure made up of the Ag4 ion, Ag6 ion and L1 is right-handed in the layer B ((b)) while the one in the layer A is left-handed. The same situations happen in the P2 ((c)), M1 ((d)), and M2 ((e)) in the layer B. It seems as if the symmetry of complex 1 should have been improved, however, the homochirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acids destroys the mirror symmetry. The fact that the complex 1 indeed crystallizes in the chiral space group is soundly supported by the Circular Dichroism. All the helical structures are also decorated by the (+)-camphor-10-sulfonic anion.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The complex 2, also crystallized in chiral space group P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, can be obtained by the utilization of L3 ((−)-camphor-10-sulfonic acid) replaced with L2 ((+)-camphor-10-sulfonic acid). The main structure resembles complex 1 (There are also two layers in the complex 2 with the name of layer A and layer B, respectively. the chirality of the helices in the two layers is opposite as well) while the helical structures are decorated by the L3, resulting the neutrally chiral undulating (6, 3) net.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The complex 2, also crystallized in chiral space group P21, can be obtained by the utilization of L3 ((-)-camphor-10-sulfonic acid) replaced with L2 ((+)-camphor-10-sulfonic acid). The main structure resembles complex 1 (There are also two layers in the complex 2 with the name of layer A and layer B, respectively. the chirality of the helices in the two layers is opposite as well) while the helical structures are decorated by the L3, resulting the neutrally chiral undulating (6, 3) net.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Circular Dichroism (CD) spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Circular Dichroism (CD) spectroscopy has emerged as a very useful technique in stereochemistry in recent years . Recently, CD spectroscopy play an indispensable role in the flourishing and promising research field of the construction of the chiral porous solids by the availability of achiral building blocks because it can provide the information of the chirality of bulk materials . However, in our research, it is used to confirm the fact that the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acids do not happen ligands racemization. The homochiral bulk materials can be obtained, meanwhile, the handedness of the bulk materials also can be regulated by the chirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acids. To examine the chiroptical and stable activities of all the enantiopure compounds in the solution state, the CD spectra of complex 1 and 2 in DMF (Dimethylformamide) have been investigated. In the wavelength range <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 260–340 nm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>), complex 1 shows positive Cotton effects at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 298 nm. The CD spectra of each pair of complexes 1 and 2 are mirror images of each other, indicating that the two pairs of compounds are the respective enantiomers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Circular Dichroism (CD) spectroscopy

Circular Dichroism (CD) spectroscopy has emerged as a very useful technique in stereochemistry in recent years . Recently, CD spectroscopy play an indispensable role in the flourishing and promising research field of the construction of the chiral porous solids by the availability of achiral building blocks because it can provide the information of the chirality of bulk materials . However, in our research, it is used to confirm the fact that the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acids do not happen ligands racemization. The homochiral bulk materials can be obtained, meanwhile, the handedness of the bulk materials also can be regulated by the chirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acids. To examine the chiroptical and stable activities of all the enantiopure compounds in the solution state, the CD spectra of complex 1 and 2 in DMF (Dimethylformamide) have been investigated. In the wavelength range λ = 260-340 nm ( ), complex 1 shows positive Cotton effects at λ = 298 nm. The CD spectra of each pair of complexes 1 and 2 are mirror images of each other, indicating that the two pairs of compounds are the respective enantiomers.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Two two-dimension homochiral Ag (I) metal frameworks were obtained by the utilization of the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid and hexamethylenetetramine. The analysis of the topology reveals that the two frameworks are (6, 3) topology decorated by the enantiopure camphor-10-sulfonic acid. There are two kinds of the layers which are made up of the helical structures including the left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical structures. Compared with the structure of two layers, it is worth noting that the handedness of all the helixes in the different layers is just opposite. The handedness of the bulk materials can be controlled by the chirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acid. Such helices decorated by the chiral molecule provide a vivid model to better understand the chirality and helix in living world because biopolymers such as proteins and DNA have acquired a definite helical sense (e.g., right handed α-helix) associated with the chirality of their molecular building blocks (e.g., <ce:small-caps>l</ce:small-caps>-amino acids or D-sugars) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two two-dimension homochiral Ag (I) metal frameworks were obtained by the utilization of the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid and hexamethylenetetramine. The analysis of the topology reveals that the two frameworks are (6, 3) topology decorated by the enantiopure camphor-10-sulfonic acid. There are two kinds of the layers which are made up of the helical structures including the left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical structures. Compared with the structure of two layers, it is worth noting that the handedness of all the helixes in the different layers is just opposite. The handedness of the bulk materials can be controlled by the chirality of the camphor-10-sulfonic acid. Such helices decorated by the chiral molecule provide a vivid model to better understand the chirality and helix in living world because biopolymers such as proteins and DNA have acquired a definite helical sense (e.g., right handed α-helix) associated with the chirality of their molecular building blocks (e.g., l-amino acids or D-sugars) .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Crystallographic data for the structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data center as supplementary publication number CCDC 779202-779203. Copy of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK (fax: t44 1223 336 033; e-mail: <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="mailto:deposit@ccdc.com.ac.uk" xlink:type="simple">deposit@ccdc.com.ac.uk</ce:inter-ref>). Supplementary data related to this article can be found online at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.solidstatesciences.2010.09.004" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.solidstatesciences.2010.09.004</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

Crystallographic data for the structure of complex 1 and complex 2 reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data center as supplementary publication number CCDC 779202-779203. Copy of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK (fax: t44 1223 336 033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.com.ac.uk). Supplementary data related to this article can be found online at doi:10.1016/j.solidstatesciences.2010.09.004.

elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

The following are the Supplementary data related to this article:

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of the two complexes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">(+)-Camphor-10-sulfonic acids (0.116 g, 0.5 mmol) and hexamine (0.5 mmol, 0.07g) were added to an aqueous solution (10 mL) of acetic acid silver (0.5 mmol, 0.084g). After the mixture was stirred for 15 min, the precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous solution of NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (14M). Colorless crystals of complex 1 were obtained by evaporation of the solution for 5 days at room temperature (52% yield). The complex 2 was obtained by the same method with the (−)-camphor-10-sulfonic acids.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the two complexes

(+)-Camphor-10-sulfonic acids (0.116 g, 0.5 mmol) and hexamine (0.5 mmol, 0.07g) were added to an aqueous solution (10 mL) of acetic acid silver (0.5 mmol, 0.084g). After the mixture was stirred for 15 min, the precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous solution of NH3 (14M). Colorless crystals of complex 1 were obtained by evaporation of the solution for 5 days at room temperature (52% yield). The complex 2 was obtained by the same method with the (-)-camphor-10-sulfonic acids.

metadata.title: Ag (I)-based 2D metal frameworks with helical structures decorated by the homochiral camphor-10-sulfonic acid
